millsfield:images_texts:
definitive contract
for the pur-
chase of five
L-1011 TriStar
jetliners valued at approx-
imately $100 million was
executed in 1972 by PSA
and Lockheed Aircraft Cor-
poration.
The new contract follows
three years of investigation
and evaluation by PSA to
find the best wide-bodied
aircraft for its quick turn-
around, personalized, com-
muter service and culmi-
nates a long study of PSA's
wide-bodied aircraft needs.
During the long eval-
uation of the TriStar. Lock-
heed and PSA teamed up
to develop many features
which will allow the airline
to
"turn the aircraft
around just as fast as the
equipment presently in use
and to give the passengers
the little "extras" they have
come to expect from PSA.
Among the new features
is the capability of loading
and off-loading a maximum
number of passengers
through four wide cabin
doors plus the unique abil-
ity to board over 100 pas-
sengers with carry-on lug-
gage through an auxiliary
entrance.
The new entrance is lo-
cated below the cabin level
and to the rear of the be-
low-cabin cocktail lounge.
Passengers with carry-on
luggage can enter through
the auxiliary door, deposit
their luggage in special
racks and proceed to either
the cocktail lounge or the
regular cabin. Upon arrival
at their destination, they
can deplane through the
same entrance after retriev-
ing their luggage from the
special compartment.
PSA will be the first air-
line to feature a below-
cabin cocktail lounge.
Complete with 16 saleable
seats, all designed for the
pER
pEA

same comfort as the pas-
senger's living room, the
lounge includes a full-serv-
ice bar and Stewardess
service
In PSA's configuration,
286 seats will be located in
the main cabin making a
total of 302 seats including
those in the lounge.
These wide, ultra-com-
fortable seats are sepa-
rated by two spacious
aisles to provide easy exit
without bumping into pas-
sengers across the aisle.
The cabin ceiling is over
eight feet high, allowing
passengers to stand up
and to enter or leave their
seats without stooping.
The new advanced cabin
interior of the L-1011 will
include coat storage facil-
ities and overhead storage
cabinets that will make it as
functional as it is beautiful.
Powered by three Rolls-
Royce engines, each gen-
erating 42,000 pounds of
thrust, the L-1011 will be
virtually smokeless and
much quieter than earlier
generation aircraft.
The first two PSA wide-
bodied TriStars will be de-
livered in the Spring
Of
1974 and the other three
will be delivered during
1975 and 1976.
Present
plans call for initial use of
the L-1011s on the high-
density Los Angeles-San
Francisco route although
the aircraft can be operated
efficiently from any of the
airports PSA serves.

acific Southwest
Airlines is tak-
ing on a new
look both on
the ground and in the air.
The familiar red and white
airplanes with the big smile
under the nose are being
repainted into a "'new
look"
Designed to compliment
the airline's changing color
scheme, fushia, orange,
red and whie sriDes ex-
tend the length of the fuse-
lace and flare up on the
vertical stabilizer like a
rooster tail.
The "new look" also in-
cludes new uniforms for pi-
lots, reservations agents,
counter agents, lobby
agents and stewardesses.
All PSA aircraft will be re-
painted throughout 1973
on a regular schedule that
will not interfere with full
utilization of the aircraft.
ncreasecoassen-
ger traffic prompt-
ed the start of an
expansion program
for the Reservations Depart-
ment in late 1972. Walls
tumbled down and a former
storeroom became part of
the department to make
room to expand the present
84 working positions to 140
positions. New telephone
equipment is being in-
stalled to handle the thou-
sands of daily calls and
waiting time is being cut so
as not to exceed eight sec-
onds.
A new computer will re-
place the former method of
providing flight information
to the reservationist. At the
touch of a button, a small
screen at the reservation-
ist's desk will indicate the
number of seats available
on a particular flight or, if
that flight is full, alternate
flights and their space
availability.
The new reservations
system is expected to be
fully operational during the
Spring of 1973.
This expanded system
will enable a caller to book
PSA Hotels and other hotel
reservations and rent-a-
cars in addition to flight
reservations.
G
n an ever-increas-
ing attempt to pro-
vide the best pos-
sible service and
convenience to the Califor-
nia air traveler, PSA ex-
panded its route system in
1972 to include Stockton
and Fresno.
Addition of these cities
came as a result of
requests from many resi-
dents of those areas who
approached PSA with a de-
sire for service.
Satellite airport service
was broadened in early
1972 by providing addi-
tional flights and new serv-
ice connecting Sacramen-
to, Hollywood/Burbank,
Oakland and San Diego.
The new service was
highlighted by first-time,
non-stop flights between
Sacramento and Holly-
wood/Burbank and be-
tween Sacramento and San
Diego. In addition, new
service was inaugurated
between Oakland and Sac-
ramento providing another
link between the Bay Area
and Northern California's
Central Valley.
The new service and ad-
ditional flights were de-
signed to alleviate traffic
congestion at busy Los An-
geles International Airport
and San Francisco Inter-
national Airport by offering
convenient flights at less
congested satellite airports.
